HUS far we have been dealing witn the adolescent age in general, we shall now proceed to consider more particularly that part of it with which the college instructor
has to deal. The adolescent of from 18-22 has the same characteristics as that of the
adolescent from 14 to 18. The difference is in the degree and manner of manifestation of
the characteristics. The college student must be looked upon as a being surcharged
With nervous force which is continually seeking manifestation along the line of least resistence, in that way which most satisfies his desires. The emotional element in him is
the same emotional life as before, except that it has become more intellectualized, more
under the control of the reason, if his education has been properly directed; otherwise it is
all the more predominating But taking the usual college freshman, his emotions must be
reckoned with as being intense and fitful, and marked by its extraordinary manifestations
of love, hate, auger, pride, loyalty, rivalry, jealousy, courage. Altruistic motives likely
have greater sway at this time than in the earlier years. He is usually sensitive and introspective On the whole, the emotions predominate over the intellect, and this fact, together with the character of these emotions, must be in mind whenever approach is made
to him either for the purposes of instruction, or for any other. By the time he reaches his
Junior and senior years, these unusual manifestations of the emotions are in most cases
toned down and have become under the control of the intellect. His interests, his judgments, his actions have risen to this higher plane, and the method of approach may
take advantage of the change
In intellectual capacity he has progressed in the power of synthesis and generalization
to some degree, largely conditioned by the four factors (1) the subjects he has studied in
school;(2) the experience he has had outside of it; (3) the direction, help and encouragement
he has had;(4) his own ability. No more definite generalization than this is passible, in so
far as I know. The instructor can usually determine the question in a short time at any
rate. Then, too, it is really the least important of all to consider. There is little need for
such, however, inasmuch • as in educational institutions facts regarding the intellect are
easily obtained and the results estimated in some more or less perfect way.
In his will power he is just as strong and as determined as before, perhaps even more
SO. Like the emotions, however, the will is more amenable to reason. Yet reason has not
gained the ascendancy by any means There are frequent spells of lassitude, and then
times when he will exhaust himself in his activity. When his mind is once made
up he is more hard to dissuade than formerly; he is essentially active and enthusiastic in
whatever he undertakes, and assumes the attitude of independence and responsibility more
than before. He must have interests of some kind to which he can give his energy, and
this is more likely to be true with the college man than with the preparatory school boy.
The tendency to give almost all his energy to one special line of activity, which will
later become his life work, is making itself manifest. And whereas before his activity
made itself felt in a great many directions in an almost equal degree, he has now chosen
one or several lines which most appeal to him, and has withdrawn his attention from the
others.

The college years constitute the period par excellence when he passes through that turmoil of fixing for himself those eternal principles which are to be used as his standard of
judging right and wrong in the world, and of &terming his relations to his Creator. With
the broader horizon, with increased intellectual power, with wider experience, he is now
able to grapple with such problems and after a struggle or longer or shorter duration, perhaps of several years, he emerges with certain definite principles which in all probability
will govern all his later thinking. It is this time also, rather than the previous, when
he really first looks upon the world seriously, and ponders what he is to do in it and for it,
his choice being determined by heredity, environment, and individual choice. It is the
time of most unstable mental equilibrium. It is the storm and stress period of life, when
responsibilities, more often exaggerated than not, begin to be realized, when opportunities
of varying kinds are suggested, when he feels the power within hint with which it seems
he can almost move the world, yet with uncertainty as to the directions in which it may
be right for him to exert his energy, and after that is decided where it is best. All these
serious conflicting conditions necessarily cause mental turmoil. And what an opportunity
there is for the educator—him whom he loves—it is too grand and beautiful and inspiring
to think of it. The reward that comes to the teachur who can reach him is more than the
paltry dollars that business may offer in excess of his meager salary.
We have in adolescence the sublime spectacle of youth being born into the life of the
race to be prepared for the battles that life brings When he enters he is resistless energyuncontrolled by reason, when he leaves it he is a mature man with the same emotional
strength as at the beginning but manifested now in accord with "the good, the true and
the beautiful" through the cultivation of the intellect and the discipline of the will.
As educational principles to be drawn from these facts of genetic psychology, I would
suggest the following as of the greatest importance. They are for the most part been
made, obvious by what has preceded, and require but little explanation
(1) The personality of the instructor should be such as to appeal to young people.
While this is in all cases true, it is nowhere so true as in the adolescent age, when the
admiration of the youth for the adult becomes so strong as to devolop into hero worship.
If the instructor wishes to make full use of this tendency in young people, he must address
himself to them in such a manner, both in and out of the lecture hell, that they will feel
that he understands them, and that he has a genuine interest in their development. Inasmuch as the intellectual occupies a subordinate place in the field of their interests, the instructor must administer to their other interests to a considerable degree, whether they be
moral, aesthetic, religious, personal, or so3ial. While it is true that it is the personality of
the instructor that enters into the life of the student far more than what he teaches, it is
just as true, that the more pleasing his personality, the deeper the impressions his teaching
makes upon them.
(2) Growing out of the above but deserving the rank of the other principles given,
the instructor should thoroughly understand the nature of adolescents.
(3) Deep intellectual interests should be developed in the student, and a serious atti_
tude toward study as preparation for after life established The truth is self-evident. As
James whits out this is to be done by building upon those interests already acquired, lead•
jug to those more advanced. But let me insert a word of caution at this point, as to the
determination of the degree of difficulty of sabject matter that should be attempted. The
fact t hat some students can do the work, is not in itself an indication of the rightfulness Of
giving that work. Adolescents can do wonders and the discovery of difficulties is often
the strongest motive for pursuit of a line of work, and when this is true the course offered
may be entirely wrong from the educational point of view. Psychology demands that the
interest and motive should abide in the subject itself.
(4) The instructor should make use of and develop the tendency to independent
thought and action.
(6) The instructor should inspire in the student enthusiastic; activity in his studies,
and in all the other legitimate activities of life. Otherwise much of the evil and the in-

(6) Economical use of the nervous energy should be planned. The unessential should
be eliminated; proper and definite directions of study given; doubts, perplexities, fears, removed; the scatter-brained lured to consecutive thinking; manias for thinking in extreme
degree restrained; and true habits of thought formed. That is, this storm and stress period
of life where so much nervous force is wasted, should be so regulated as to give to the student, when he emerges from it, the maximum amount of plwer.
(7) The practical bearing of the subject matter of instruction upon life, present and
future, should always be clear in the mind of the student. He should always think the
subject worthy of all the energy that he can give to it, and be able to state the reasons
therefor. Otherwise he is departing from his normal attitude towards things.
(8) The individuality of the student should be properly cared for, that its strong
Points may be preserved, and its weak points strengthened.
.(9) Opportunity for the student to express his thoughts freely and with the benefit of
criticism should be afforded. No mental process is complete until it has found expression.
All instruction should provide for it. It may best be done by free oral discussion or under
direction by set debate.
We are now ready to proceed to inquire into the question in how far do the systems
of instruction prevailing in colleges fulfill these laws? These systems may be classified
into three—(1) the lecture system; (2) the text book and recitation system; (3) the combination of the two.
The character of a lecture course differs with the character of the lecturer. Some
courses are almost purely informational. in so far as the product derived from them is concerned. In others there is a personal element contributed by a lecturer that is very
valuable, These two features must be separated in a discussion of the system as a 'whole.
First, the lecture in HO far as it is informative. If we review this kind of lecture, in
the light of these principles, it must be unhesitatingly condemned Only one of them
will, in all probability, be fulfilled, that of making clear the practical bearing of the subject matter upon life, and in many cases it fails in this as well. The preponderance of
evidence is overwhelmingly against its achieving (1) the awakening of deep intellectual
interests; (2) the developing of independent thought; (8) the inspiration to enthusiastic
activity; (4) the insuring of an economical use of nervous energy; (5) the full development
of the individuality; (6) the giving of opportunity for expression of thought The first and
Second principles cannot be applied in this connection.
And furthermore, and sufficient in itself alone to mark it as a very imperfect method
of procedure even though the truth be not strictly educational, such a means is not the best
to give information. The notes taken are not a fair and true synopsis of the lecture given
Great labor upon the part of the student is needed to prepare their imperfect reproduction
properly, and so on The lecturer in these days owes the student a printed book, and if
the matter of his lectures is worth publication, he will not have difficulty in securing a
publisher. Or if this is not possible, he may make good use, and from the students' standpoint better use of a book written by another.
The personal element in a lecture is of very great value indeed in securing the results
to be achieved in the above enumeration of principles. But the best use of personalty is
not being made in giving an informative lecture. To this we shall return later.
(2) With the text book and the recitation system as great a variety of results is secured
as with the lecture system, depending again upon the instructor. On the whole it is better
than the lecture system. For a mere reading of a book with the reflections that a student

student has the benefit of exchange of thought upon the text with his fellows. This method
is open to two objections at least. (1) It is not practicable with the organization of most
colleges as at present constituted. (2) It is narrowing in its effect if it confines attention to
one text.
The ideal as I view it, is the combination of the text book and lecture system. There
is value in the lecture, and it must be recognized; likewise there is value in the use of a
text. If I were asked to submit a plan after which college instruction might be best
modeled, it wottld be the following:
(I) Lectures for the purposes of inspiration, direction, amplification, of the nature of
new matter not contained in texts, or a comparison of the views of different authors with
the lecturer's own individual interpretation, thereby giving a clearer differentiation, or for
the purpose of summarizing.
These lectures should be given by the man most fitted in personality, knowledge, and
experience, and at those times that would best aid the student according to the principles
indicated above.
(2) A text that would give the outline of the course in such a way as to guide the
thought of the student. This is not a necessity if the following factors supply the same
need.
(3) A well stocked library. Not one or two copies of every book referred to during
the courie, though this is good, but in preference many copies of a few books which are
written upon lines similar to that followed by the course. This would be comparable to a
Physical or chemical laboratory where each student has his desk.
(4) Assistants to the lecturer of the right personality and in sufficient number, so that
every student may, come in close and frequent contact with one assistant at least. The
duties of the assistants would be:(1) to direct study,(2) to consult upon difficult points met
by pupils in study or to help him in it in every way,(3) to conduct frequent discussions
upon the reading and lectures at stated periods with the students in his charge. They
would then carry the burden of the work. In a small college the lecturer might act in this
capacity as well. But if the burden be too great for one man, and additional assistants be
needed, he ought to take part of this work, alternating at intervals with the assistants,
that he may come in contact with all the students.
With this plan I believe those principles could be fully achieved, and although it involves a change of administration of college courses, which have good arguments in their
favor as at present constituted, yet I believe the colleges are more and more coming to
some such plan as this, and that this movement will be hastened when more care is taken
to ascertain the real needs of their students.

THE CECIL RHODES' SCHOLARSHIPS.
RESIDENT REMSEN went to Philadelphia last week to meet several
educators of New Jersey and Pennsylvania in conference with a repre
sentative of the Cecil . Rhodes Trustees for the arrangement of details for
the award of the scholarships to Oxford University, provided by the will of the
great South African promoter. The conference was held in the office of Provost
Harrison, President Wilson, of Princeton, being another of those in attendance.
Preliminary plans in the same manner had already been made by several New
England States. The Philadelphia meeting passed a resolution, of which the
most interesting clause for us is this:
"In Maryland th.- nomination of Rhodes scholars for the State shall be
intrusted to a committee of from three to five members chosen from the college
faculties of the State by the president of Johns Hopkins University, of which
committee he shall be chairman.
"The selection of candidates shall be limited: To persons not less than 19
or more than 23 years of age: to persons who for at least two years shall have
been regularly enrolled students of an American college."
The New Jersey and Pennsylvania committees will be determined in a
similar way by President Wilson and Provost Harrison.
Two scholars will be named in each State, each scholarship continuing
three years with an income each year of $300.
The precise method by which the Maryland scholars will be selected, next
to the names of the men themselves, is of course the most pertinent subject for
Present speculation. President Remsen does not yet know himself, nor had he
even named the rest of the committee when this went to press.
''A great deal of thought will be required," said Dr. Remsen, early this
week, "to determine just the right methods of selection. 'What academic qualifications will make a man eligible' is probably the first question that those most
interested will ask us. It shall be understood, therefore, at the outset that we
must be reasonably assured that whomsoever we recommend shall be able to
meet the regular requirements for entrance to Oxford University. 'Responsions'
is the term by which these examinations are known. The responsions may be
regarded in a general sense as the Oxford man's matriculation examination, to
use the term current here. They differ, however, in content from our entrance
examinations, demanding from the candidate more of some things and not so
much of others. Latin, Greek, and mathematics are the most important elements of the responsions. The requirements in Greek, in particular, will probably seem unusually severe to most American students. And this requirement
cannot be waived by the substitution of something else, as is often in American
schools. What formal test will be applied by the committee itself I am not yet
able to say."
"Then, you know, Mr. Rhodes' will expresses certain preferences concerning the general character of the men who are to fill his scholarships. These
must also be observed. It will be with us to recommend young men, vigorous
and devoted to outdoor life, men best fitted by good fellowship to enter with the
best spirit into their intercourse with other men."

Honor System in the undergraduate department. There are differences
among the men as to the method to be pursued in attaining the desired
end , This is but natural; the system requires careful consideration, and there

The only word of criticism which has been heard is to the effect that the

offenses upon which they base their plea for the need of an Honor System. Such
is not the case. The men who have taken a lively interest in behalf of this
measure have not made a single statement of existing conditions which any ob-

No one can but believe that a solution will be found for this vexing
problem. The greatest difficulty lies in the method to be pursued in attaining

HUS far we have been dealing witn the adolescent age in general, we shall now proceed to consider more particularly that part of it with which the college instructor
has to deal. The adolescent of from 18-22 has the same characteristics as that of the
adolescent from 14 to 18. The difference is in the degree and manner of manifestation of
the characteristics. The college student must be looked upon as a being surcharged
With nervous force which is continually seeking manifestation along the line of least resistence, in that way which most satisfies his desires. The emotional element in him is
the same emotional life as before, except that it has become more intellectualized, more
under the control of the reason, if his education has been properly directed; otherwise it is
all the more predominating But taking the usual college freshman, his emotions must be
reckoned with as being intense and fitful, and marked by its extraordinary manifestations
of love, hate, auger, pride, loyalty, rivalry, jealousy, courage. Altruistic motives likely
have greater sway at this time than in the earlier years. He is usually sensitive and introspective On the whole, the emotions predominate over the intellect, and this fact, together with the character of these emotions, must be in mind whenever approach is made
to him either for the purposes of instruction, or for any other. By the time he reaches his
Junior and senior years, these unusual manifestations of the emotions are in most cases
toned down and have become under the control of the intellect. His interests, his judgments, his actions have risen to this higher plane, and the method of approach may
take advantage of the change
In intellectual capacity he has progressed in the power of synthesis and generalization
to some degree, largely conditioned by the four factors (1) the subjects he has studied in
school;(2) the experience he has had outside of it; (3) the direction, help and encouragement
he has had;(4) his own ability. No more definite generalization than this is passible, in so
far as I know. The instructor can usually determine the question in a short time at any
rate. Then, too, it is really the least important of all to consider. There is little need for
such, however, inasmuch • as in educational institutions facts regarding the intellect are
easily obtained and the results estimated in some more or less perfect way.
In his will power he is just as strong and as determined as before, perhaps even more
SO. Like the emotions, however, the will is more amenable to reason. Yet reason has not
gained the ascendancy by any means There are frequent spells of lassitude, and then
times when he will exhaust himself in his activity. When his mind is once made
up he is more hard to dissuade than formerly; he is essentially active and enthusiastic in
whatever he undertakes, and assumes the attitude of independence and responsibility more
than before. He must have interests of some kind to which he can give his energy, and
this is more likely to be true with the college man than with the preparatory school boy.
The tendency to give almost all his energy to one special line of activity, which will
later become his life work, is making itself manifest. And whereas before his activity
made itself felt in a great many directions in an almost equal degree, he has now chosen
one or several lines which most appeal to him, and has withdrawn his attention from the
others.

The college years constitute the period par excellence when he passes through that turmoil of fixing for himself those eternal principles which are to be used as his standard of
judging right and wrong in the world, and of &terming his relations to his Creator. With
the broader horizon, with increased intellectual power, with wider experience, he is now
able to grapple with such problems and after a struggle or longer or shorter duration, perhaps of several years, he emerges with certain definite principles which in all probability
will govern all his later thinking. It is this time also, rather than the previous, when
he really first looks upon the world seriously, and ponders what he is to do in it and for it,
his choice being determined by heredity, environment, and individual choice. It is the
time of most unstable mental equilibrium. It is the storm and stress period of life, when
responsibilities, more often exaggerated than not, begin to be realized, when opportunities
of varying kinds are suggested, when he feels the power within hint with which it seems
he can almost move the world, yet with uncertainty as to the directions in which it may
be right for him to exert his energy, and after that is decided where it is best. All these
serious conflicting conditions necessarily cause mental turmoil. And what an opportunity
there is for the educator—him whom he loves—it is too grand and beautiful and inspiring
to think of it. The reward that comes to the teachur who can reach him is more than the
paltry dollars that business may offer in excess of his meager salary.
We have in adolescence the sublime spectacle of youth being born into the life of the
race to be prepared for the battles that life brings When he enters he is resistless energyuncontrolled by reason, when he leaves it he is a mature man with the same emotional
strength as at the beginning but manifested now in accord with "the good, the true and
the beautiful" through the cultivation of the intellect and the discipline of the will.
As educational principles to be drawn from these facts of genetic psychology, I would
suggest the following as of the greatest importance. They are for the most part been
made, obvious by what has preceded, and require but little explanation
(1) The personality of the instructor should be such as to appeal to young people.
While this is in all cases true, it is nowhere so true as in the adolescent age, when the
admiration of the youth for the adult becomes so strong as to devolop into hero worship.
If the instructor wishes to make full use of this tendency in young people, he must address
himself to them in such a manner, both in and out of the lecture hell, that they will feel
that he understands them, and that he has a genuine interest in their development. Inasmuch as the intellectual occupies a subordinate place in the field of their interests, the instructor must administer to their other interests to a considerable degree, whether they be
moral, aesthetic, religious, personal, or so3ial. While it is true that it is the personality of
the instructor that enters into the life of the student far more than what he teaches, it is
just as true, that the more pleasing his personality, the deeper the impressions his teaching
makes upon them.
(2) Growing out of the above but deserving the rank of the other principles given,
the instructor should thoroughly understand the nature of adolescents.
(3) Deep intellectual interests should be developed in the student, and a serious atti_
tude toward study as preparation for after life established The truth is self-evident. As
James whits out this is to be done by building upon those interests already acquired, lead•
jug to those more advanced. But let me insert a word of caution at this point, as to the
determination of the degree of difficulty of sabject matter that should be attempted. The
fact t hat some students can do the work, is not in itself an indication of the rightfulness Of
giving that work. Adolescents can do wonders and the discovery of difficulties is often
the strongest motive for pursuit of a line of work, and when this is true the course offered
may be entirely wrong from the educational point of view. Psychology demands that the
interest and motive should abide in the subject itself.
(4) The instructor should make use of and develop the tendency to independent
thought and action.
(6) The instructor should inspire in the student enthusiastic; activity in his studies,
and in all the other legitimate activities of life. Otherwise much of the evil and the in-

modeled, it wottld be the following:
(I) Lectures for the purposes of inspiration, direction, amplification, of the nature of
new matter not contained in texts, or a comparison of the views of different authors with
the lecturer's own individual interpretation, thereby giving a clearer differentiation, or for
the purpose of summarizing.
These lectures should be given by the man most fitted in personality, knowledge, and
experience, and at those times that would best aid the student according to the principles
indicated above.
(2) A text that would give the outline of the course in such a way as to guide the
thought of the student. This is not a necessity if the following factors supply the same
need.
(3) A well stocked library. Not one or two copies of every book referred to during
the courie, though this is good, but in preference many copies of a few books which are
written upon lines similar to that followed by the course. This would be comparable to a
Physical or chemical laboratory where each student has his desk.
(4) Assistants to the lecturer of the right personality and in sufficient number, so that
every student may, come in close and frequent contact with one assistant at least. The
duties of the assistants would be:(1) to direct study,(2) to consult upon difficult points met
by pupils in study or to help him in it in every way,(3) to conduct frequent discussions
upon the reading and lectures at stated periods with the students in his charge. They
would then carry the burden of the work. In a small college the lecturer might act in this
capacity as well. But if the burden be too great for one man, and additional assistants be
needed, he ought to take part of this work, alternating at intervals with the assistants,
that he may come in contact with all the students.
With this plan I believe those principles could be fully achieved, and although it involves a change of administration of college courses, which have good arguments in their
favor as at present constituted, yet I believe the colleges are more and more coming to
some such plan as this, and that this movement will be hastened when more care is taken
to ascertain the real needs of their students.

THE CECIL RHODES' SCHOLARSHIPS.
RESIDENT REMSEN went to Philadelphia last week to meet several
educators of New Jersey and Pennsylvania in conference with a repre
sentative of the Cecil . Rhodes Trustees for the arrangement of details for
the award of the scholarships to Oxford University, provided by the will of the
great South African promoter. The conference was held in the office of Provost
Harrison, President Wilson, of Princeton, being another of those in attendance.
Preliminary plans in the same manner had already been made by several New
England States. The Philadelphia meeting passed a resolution, of which the
most interesting clause for us is this:
"In Maryland th.- nomination of Rhodes scholars for the State shall be
intrusted to a committee of from three to five members chosen from the college
faculties of the State by the president of Johns Hopkins University, of which
committee he shall be chairman.
"The selection of candidates shall be limited: To persons not less than 19
or more than 23 years of age: to persons who for at least two years shall have
been regularly enrolled students of an American college."
The New Jersey and Pennsylvania committees will be determined in a
similar way by President Wilson and Provost Harrison.
Two scholars will be named in each State, each scholarship continuing
three years with an income each year of $300.
The precise method by which the Maryland scholars will be selected, next
to the names of the men themselves, is of course the most pertinent subject for
Present speculation. President Remsen does not yet know himself, nor had he
even named the rest of the committee when this went to press.
''A great deal of thought will be required," said Dr. Remsen, early this
week, "to determine just the right methods of selection. 'What academic qualifications will make a man eligible' is probably the first question that those most
interested will ask us. It shall be understood, therefore, at the outset that we
must be reasonably assured that whomsoever we recommend shall be able to
meet the regular requirements for entrance to Oxford University. 'Responsions'
is the term by which these examinations are known. The responsions may be
regarded in a general sense as the Oxford man's matriculation examination, to
use the term current here. They differ, however, in content from our entrance
examinations, demanding from the candidate more of some things and not so
much of others. Latin, Greek, and mathematics are the most important elements of the responsions. The requirements in Greek, in particular, will probably seem unusually severe to most American students. And this requirement
cannot be waived by the substitution of something else, as is often in American
schools. What formal test will be applied by the committee itself I am not yet
able to say."
"Then, you know, Mr. Rhodes' will expresses certain preferences concerning the general character of the men who are to fill his scholarships. These
must also be observed. It will be with us to recommend young men, vigorous
and devoted to outdoor life, men best fitted by good fellowship to enter with the
best spirit into their intercourse with other men."

INTERCLASS ATHLETIC CONTESTS.
HE first annual interclass athletic meet came off in the "cage" last Thursday night. The cage had been elaborately decorated with the championship banners which Hopkins has won, and together with the flags of the
Classes of 1903 and 1904, the walls and rafters were decked in true gala attire.
These banners are the proofs of the athletic excellence to which Hopkins has
attained, while the "vim" and "vigor" manifested by the contestants in the
various contests showed that this excellence is still to remain above par.
During the course of the evening several genuine surprises were encountered, first among them being the result of the mile run. Porter was picked
for a sure winner, and Nelson's fast pace and the good form in which he ran
were totally unexpected. While Nelson's work on the track has always been
very creditable, still he has never been numbered among the fastest long-distance -runners. He shows unusual promise. Captain Hoffman will no doubt
be able to use him to advantage for the Varsity.
The second surprise came in the relay race. The Seniors won out by a
broad margin, as was expected, but the defeat of the Juniors by the Freshmen
created a little surprise. The Freshmen ran in good form, Stone's pace against
LeCron being particularly commendable.
Surprise No. 3 came in the half mile run, when Harry Tootle carried off
first honors. Heretofore, Tootle has been counted on to figure conspicuously
in the dashes, but he has never posed as a long distance man, and his exhibition proves him to be a valuable runner in either long or short distance.
The thirty yard dash came off in first class style, and both Pessagno and
Blanck did pretty work in the running high jump.
A large crowd attended, and we may expect Manager Dulaney to report a
financial success.

VALUABLE ADDITION TO THE STROUSE SEMETIC LIBRARY.
HROUGH the generosity of Mr. Leopold Strouse the Strouse Semetic
Library has been enriched by a collection of books that will give to this
department of the University the most valuable library of the kind in
the country. The Strouse Semetic Library was founded about six years ago by
Mr. Strouse, who has been making additions to it from time to time. The
present donatiOn is, however, the most generous ever made, and its benefits to
the department, and to the University in general cannot be overestimated. Mr.
Strouse recently learned that the library of Mr. S Schwartzberger, a prominent
Hebrew scholar of New York, was on sale, and he commissioned Dr. Rosenau,
Fellow by courtesy in Semetic languages, to go to New York and examine the
library with a view of purchasing the most valuable volumes. Dr. Rosenau
found that the library contained many rare and valuable works, which he
promptly secured. The new books, which number about 1500 volumes, many
of them out of print, embrace all phases of Hebrew literature, including philosophy, poetry, history, biography, legal enactments, and natural sciences. The
collection arrived at the University several days ago, and is now being catalogued. Public formal announcement of the gift will be made on Commemoration Day.
